data.formatted_address: 1-５１ Nishikurachō, Minato Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 455-0034, Japan
data.name: Nagoya Port Sea Train Land

reviews.text: A small amusement park near the bay close to the Nagoya aquarium. Worth spending time here as it gave a local vibe and the view from the ferris wheel is very beautiful😇

Nagoya Port Sea Train Land is a beautiful, family-friendly attraction that our kids thoroughly enjoyed. The atmosphere was lively and welcoming, with many fun activities and amenities to entertain little ones. 😘😘

You can spend time here with good activities
Aquarium is also there
Small but heartwarming and nostalgic amusement park next to Nagoya port. Nice and friendly staff. Easy to access just 5 minutes walk from subway. Good for couple and family.

It is an amazing park for the kids and as well as adults. This is situated nesr Nagoya port dolphin park. There is no entry fee needed. There are some traditional rides are kept. Merry go round. Horse racing rides etc. If any ine wants to ride on every rides for meny time as they want can buy a norihoudai ticket. Norihoudai is a japanese word that means you can ride meny times as you want to ride. Like as buffet. :p eat as you like. On that case 2500 yen needed for this ticket. This price is for student those who are carrying student id card. Merry go round ride is as usual awesome. It is amazing port view from the merry go round car. Merry go round entry fee is 700 yen.  Nagoya port dolphin park also can be seen from this ride.  Other rides are also awesome. Anyone can spend their holidays with Nagoya port park and as well as this sea train land park in a day

data.formatted_address: LEGOLAND Japan Limited, 1 Kinjoufutou, 2-chōme-2 Kinjōfutō, Minato Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 455-8605, Japan
data.name: Legoland Japan Resort

reviews.text:
Not just for kids! Our family with teenagers had an awesome time at Legoland Nagoya in April 2024.
The rainy day kept the weekend crowds away, so we had literally no wait time for most rides. We rode The Dragon roller-coaster twice consecutively with no wait time.
The longest we waited was ~5 minutes for the Submarine ride, but it was well worth it!
As the rain got heavier, some rides were closed, but we were lucky enough to do the main ones before the rain got too much.

All in, we spent about 6 hours there, and I wish I could have spent more time looking at the Mini world. Stunning!

Things to note:
- Food is plentiful but very expensive inside and you cannot bring your own.
- The Lego box prices in The Big Store are not any cheaper than what you can buy in normal retail at home (Australia for me).
- The Big Store can hold your luggage for a fee (Y10,000) if they are too large to fit in a locker.
- Taxi service is available from the Lego Hotel, just outside the gates.

I had a blast here! I was not expecting to have as much fun as I did, me and my 20s year old friends booked the tickets and didn’t have high expectations, but we were surprised on how many cool attractions are there. Not only kids and family, but also adults can have a lot of fun, several attractions. My favorites are the water ones which provided a great refreshment to the warm weather. I had fun as I was a kid again!

The only improvement point I would say it’s the food court, we tried the Lego sandwich and it was below average and a bit pricey.

Overall, totally worth the visit!!

The greatest amusement theme park for little children. Kindergarten children will very enjoy. My daughter loved here more than Disney Land. She could play almost every rides.

No super famous mascots like other World class theme park, but can feel in with every Lego mascots here. I arrived here before open time.At the entrance had some attractions these you could enjoy them.

Admission ticket fees were much cheaper than Disney Land and Universal Studio. I bought entrance tickets online, cheaper and more convenient.

Easy to transportation. Subway and walk about 10-15 minutes. Children with stroller was easy to walk with elevators.

Most of guests here were family trip with little children. Lego small town was very impressive than I thought. They had atrractive and interesting movements.

Food courts was great value, reasonable prices, nice taste and not too crowd. Refill beverages made feel like stay in oasis. Everyone could enjoy tasty foods and refreshments.

Highly recommend for full one day with family trip. Little children would impressed and very enjoy here.

I'm so happy to bring the kids to Legoland!!! It was easy to get to Legoland. (We went on a weekday, Thursday.) The train was not cramped and we were able to get seats from Nagoya station. Given that there were about 10 stops, the family was able to sit comfortably.

The park felt empty compared to other theme parks like Disney and Universal Studios but it was perfect for me especially when your kids are below 10. The rides are perfect for kids their age. Not too boring, not too scary. I have 2 boys with me, aged 7 and 11. They enjoyed that there was no queue and they can repeat rides. It's like VVIP skip pass! We were able to try out all the rides!!!

Food is also reasonably priced. We tried the burger place.

Personal favorite rides: surfer, dragon roller coaster, ninja go ride and submarine!!! The submarine was an awesome experience.

Too much to see and explore in one day! We had so much fun, kids and grown ups too! Don’t miss the Ninjago live show (3-4 times daily - check showtime in website or ask the staff there) . For restaurant, recommend going to the traditional japanese one (on the right side of park next to the Ninjago live show theatre) - drinks is all-you-can-drink style.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒460-0008 Aichi, Nagoya, Naka Ward, Sakae, 2-chōme−17−１ 芸術と科学の杜・白川公園内
data.name: Nagoya City Science Museum

reviews.text:
This is a really varied and dynamic museum, with lots of interactive exhibitions, informative signs to read and a really, really amazing planetarium. It can be quite busy on the day, so it's best to get tickets in advance lest you end up waiting in a very long line on a hot day!

The central location is very nice though, which makes it easy to get to. There's something here for everyone, whether you are a child, adult or a just interested in science in general!

It was first time to visit Nagoya with two children. They are 10 and 13 years old and enjoyed the place so much. We couldn’t get out of there even though we (I and my husband) became very tired.
We booked the tickets like special exhibition and planetarium a day before. When we got to the science museum, there was a long queue to buy tickets.
Highly recommend this place for whom with children!

The museum was so much fun to explore and they had really cool exhibits on every floor! Unfortunately the planetarium was closed when we went but I can imagine that would be awesome to see as well. I enjoyed the special exhibit they had going on, it did take us a minute to find it though as the stairs to the basement aren’t in the same place as the the main escalators we saw everyone taking. Definitely a kid friendly place and lots of things you can interact with.

It has 6 floors!! Filled to the brim with practical science areas where you can watch the theory be turned into practice. I loved the tornado simulation, it was stunning! There where a lot of school kids visiting though, from young to old children who made heaps of noise but where respectful of those around them.

I had an incredible experience at the Nagoya City Science Museum! The exhibits were fascinating, offering a wide range of interactive and educational displays that kept both adults and children engaged for hours. The planetarium show was particularly captivating, providing a mesmerizing journey through the cosmos. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, enhancing the overall experience. With its diverse range of exhibits and hands-on activities, the museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in science and technology. Highly recommended!

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-2-2 Kinjōfutō, Minato Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 455-0848, Japan
data.name: SCMaglev and Railway Park

reviews.text: This is the BEST museum I’ve ever been to🔥 At first glance you think it’s a normal museum but then you explore it closely and it is just amazing🤩 They have so many hands on simulators and experiences that clearly show how the Railway in japan works👌 It’s a great place to bring your kids along I’m sure they will love it❤️ You can see the trains from inside how they are and how they were in the past…. What all changes they have been through and so much more😁 Must visit at least once👍

A must visit museum when you visit Nagoya Japan.
All train from Japan’s history are displayed here. Showing the evolution of the train before till now.
Have lots of interactive attractions for all to learn, enjoy and have fun.
Wether you’re kid or an adult you will surely be amazed with what you see and experience in the museum.
The have a good food station to have your lunch or snack to get you going on your tour. The place is quite big and have lot to read and explore.

Spectacular museum of Japanese trains accessible via a short 24 minute train ride from Nagoya Station. This museum has an example of every model Shinkansen train along with rail cars from the over 100 year history of Japanese trains. Interactive exhibits for every age group explain the history and science behind Japanese high speed rail.  You will not regret spending a few hours at this Japanese treasure.

Great railway museum, very popular with families.
Exhibitions are primarily in Japanese but with highlights in English.
It would be great if there were more information published in English for tourists.
The diorama is lovely but there are definitely better ones in Europe.

Very nice place for people who love trains and technology in general. A couple of hours is enough to explore every corner of the museum. Has a wide range of interactive media that explain the Japanese train history and its development, I was personally intrigued by the train diorama they had. Very informative for kids too! Thanks for the wonderful place!

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-1-36 Noritakeshinmachi, Nishi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 451-8501, Japan
data.name: Noritake Garden

reviews.text:
Visited Noridake's Forest on Sunday morning. It rained a little, but there were people and it was not noisy or crowded.
There were many people who took a quiet walk in the garden rather than several exhibition halls and museums, so it was relaxing. The park site in front of the ION Mall, which is directly connected, was well established, so it was good to visit with children.
In front of the ion mall, there was also a ceramic wall built of pottery pieces

By the way, there is a Tatsuya bookstore in Ion Mall. The walls of huge books are wonderful
Please try to be here if you stay in Nagoya. Very peaceful place and you can take a good rest. And enjoy some food and shopping in AEON mall here.

Noritake Garden is a place where people can enjoy many things. The garden has European-style red brick buildings. The landscaping has flowing water and green plants. See historic structures like the six chimneys built in 1933.

There is a Tsutaya Book store for those who love to read, featuring high wall with books from floor to ceiling.

Aeon mall has many shops as well.
Quiet and clean. The Garden includes Noritake Museum and Exhibition Hall which allows people learn more about the history of Japanese ceramics.

calm and cozy place!!
Aeon mall is right next to the Noritake Garden, so you can enjoy shopping as well.

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-23 Shumokuchō, Higashi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 461-0014, Japan
data.name: Cultural Path Futaba Museum

reviews.text:
Futaba Museum is the former home of Japan’s first actress, Sadayakko Kawakami, and Momosuke Fukuzawa, a power station pioneer and tycoon. The house, was built in 1920, but originally located in Higashi-Futaba-cho. It was relocated to its current location in 2000 and restoration was completed in 2005. The residence is now a designated cultural property.The house, nicknamed the “Futaba Palace”, had a revolutionary design and the interior was stocked with electrical fittings that were groundbreaking at the time. Such was the influence of the occupants, that the house was regularly visited by political, financial, and cultural guests.

Guided tours are available, which last 30 minutes but are conducted in Japanese, though a detailed English leaflet is available. Entry is 200 Yen.The closest metro station is Takaoka Station (Sakuradori Line) or you can take the sightseeing bus which has a stop right outside the museum.

One of the antique western style mansion complex in this area. Relatively big and more to see...colored glass windows and Japanese room are something to see.
There's a cafe using a part of it.
Small museum, but the admission price is low and it is worth going for those that appreciate old homes and the fact the home belonged to Japan's first modern actress makes it even more worthwhile.

It is a traditional building in my neighborhood.
I love the Futabakan.It played an important role to promote electrification in Japan at Meiji era.

One of many interesting houses in this Cultural Path of Nagoya (Bunka no Michi). We didn't go into the house due to time constraints, but wandering the grounds and admiring the architecture was also a treat! The Sightseeing Bus (Me-guru) stops right outside this house, and is worth the 500yen price as it takes u thru a loop of the city covering many interesting places!

data.formatted_address: 2 Chome-17 Sakae, Naka Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 460-0008, Japan
data.name: Shirakawa Park

reviews.text: It's a good place to stop and have a rest in between trips to the shopping district. Surrounded by trees is a large field in the middle, good for playing sports. Plenty of seats around the fountain by the Science Museum, allowing you to enjoy the view.
Spacious and good for excercise. Thus park is where City Science museum is located. Best value for a Science Museum. Learned alot for just JPY400 entrance fee. Great floor on Space
A cool and nice place to chill, you can see the science museum. There is a big fountain and a sun clock.
A small city park with two main attractions, the Nogoya Science and Art museums. Each a short walk from the other.
Well maintained park (in terms of cleanliness and greens). Can see/access the science museum and the city art museum at this park. Quite a photogenic area with water fountains, ponds and public art.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-2-25 Meijō, Kita Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 462-0846, Japan
data.name: Meijō Park

reviews.text:
A big park,people enjoyed running,walking,picnic,read their books.Its very calming,relaxing  & peaceful,you can smell the  fresh air.
Been here during wisteria season & its so beautiful.
It can be noisy from time to time due to the recent construction work, but it's not full of people. It's not so bad for resting overall.
A huge beautiful park adjacent to Nagoya Castle. Lots of space to lay and lots of beautiful scenery to enjoy.
2024/04/02 Saw some very beautiful cherry blossoms.
North of Nagoya Castle. Free to enter. Has a Starbucks. Across the road is a sibway

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒466-0064 Aichi, Nagoya, Showa Ward, Tsurumai, 1-chōme−1−１６８ 緑化センター
data.name: Nagoya City Greenery Center

reviews.text: Good place for walk and jogging.

Activities such as greening promotion
There is a small greenhouse inside and a cute fountain.
There is a garden around the outer periphery, and it is famous for Suifuyou.
I happened to pass by on a weekday Monday. I didn't know that there was a facility like this in Tsuruma Park. I wanted to see the greenhouse, but unfortunately it was closed.

It seems that some sort of event is being held in the lobby and experience space on the first floor.
There was also a small greenhouse.
It didn't feel like I could learn anything.
There seems to be a training venue on the second floor, so it seems that classes and training related to greening are being held.

GW was the best time to see roses. I feel like the irises are in the future. Quiz rally forms were available at the greening center, so we enjoyed taking quizzes while walking around the park. I thought it would be nice if the participation prize was a seed, but it wasn't 😂 It looks like pansies and violas will be replanted with summer flowers in May.

data.formatted_address: 1-1 Honmaru, Naka Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 460-0031, Japan
data.name: Nagoya Castle

reviews.text: A nice castle but slightly smaller than other castles. It was a great experience to be able to walk through a section of the castle (not the main castle) where the rooms were re-enacted with the Hinoki wood. Explanations/contents were available in English and clearly written. Overall, a wonderful experience for young and old. The surrounding park offers a nice stroll too.

Japan is fantastic for low cost educational children's activities. Nagoya castle and palace is another great example of that.

Sadly the original palace burnt down during WWII, however the replica was constructed and is stunning. Beautiful grounds and gardens and bucketloads of history.

Ninjas and samurai roam the grounds too.

Lots of food options outside the castle grounds.

Well worth a visit even if briefly.
A bit smaller than other castles I've been to in Japan, but still worth a visit. Was quite a long wait to get inside on a hot summer day, so keep that in mind, but otherwise was a great experience.

When visiting Japan one must visit Nagoya, more specifically Nagoya Castle. The entrance fee is 500 Yen which you can pay by cash or credit care.

The castle is an architectural masterpiece. It really shows that the Japanese people have a true sense of detail and discipline.

The staff at this location is super friendly.  There are concessions stands inside the walls and the food is amazingly good and super cheap!

Due to earthquake damage the castle is currently closed to the public however the site can be visited.

There are many different castles, but the mint green of Nagoya Castle was a wonderful color.
I heard that cherry blossoms are in full bloom depending on the season (March~April).There is a parking lot nearby, and there is space for two-wheeled vehicles.Street plays and other events can be seen on the central street.
There are food stalls where you can have a light meal.

data.formatted_address: 1017 Tokugawachō, Higashi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 461-0023, Japan
data.name: The Tokugawa Art Museum

reviews.text: I went there when I first came here in Nagoya I knew it was a popular place the garden and the museum need separate tickets but they have a discount for students so It was less for me at that time.

Y1600 per person at the counter
Garden combo tickets are Y1750

Apparently the museum tickets are Y1400 when you buy online in advance and the garden ticket without discount is Y300
So you’d save Y50

Didn’t plan to visit after reading some negative reviews about it being too expensive for what it’s worth but we actually really enjoyed hanging there on a rainy day. The hina dolls miniatures from 18-19th centuries were very impressive. The museum was very well built and photography was only prohibited on a few private collections.

Also thankful for the free museum parking at the back!

The collections are priceless, if you are into warring state history, this is a must go.
Plus the souvenirs are very unique, some of them are only available in this museum and they are just perfect and well designed, I noticed the general design language of this museum is very good too.

Btw lockers are provided for medium to large size luggage, and the usual 100 yen locker.

I recommend buying a ticket for the garden as well as the museum. Even though it was snowing, I was able to scroll the expensive gardens and enjoy the peaceful scenery. The museum itself was astonishing. I guess because of the cold weather it was not very crowded when I visited on a weekday afternoon. I was able to spend a lot of time in the space enjoying Noh masks and a stage as well as famous swords and household objects. Having space and quiet allowed me to imagine living at that time. It’s such an intimate portrayal of daily life compared to a place like Nikkō Tōshō-gū, which is far more elaborate.

Nice museum showcasing the feudal lord's ancestral possessions. Very beautiful items are on display and the lacquer work items are outstanding. Lovely craftsmanship.
Entrance tickets are quite expensive @Yen 1600 per adult. Could see, but you need to spend at least 2 hours here and it closes at 5pm

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-50 Ikeshita, Chikusa Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 464-0066, Japan
data.name: Furukawa Art Museum

reviews.text: This is such a magnificent museum with two parts. Start at the old building which is conserved as a traditional tea house. Enjoy the art and the wonderful quiet and greenery. Then walk down the road to the modern art museum and enjoy the more modern paintings.

Thank you for a wonderful time. This place truly is Nagoya local gem. Do buy a combo ticket for 800yen if you show their webpage, but sold exclusively at the main building.
Easy excess from the station but a very limited parking place which was hard to find thus ended up wasting 800yen extra. However, things on display were amazing and despite the limited number of items, it is a very nice place to come with your kid and introduce the art
Do visit their cafe that offers absolutely yummy traditional sweets and has a stunning garden to appreciate while sipping on Matcha.
YES RECOMMENDED for kids 4+
The unspoken secret. Not a big gallery but the residence gallery section is a perfect getaway from the hustle bustle. Not recommend for kids under 12.
Small museum in a quiet neighborhood. Entry fee is ¥1000.
Good

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒460-0008 Aichi, Nagoya, Naka Ward, Sakae, 2-chōme−17−２５ 芸術と科学の杜・白川公園内
data.name: Nagoya City Art Museum

reviews.text: It was fascinating!! There were multiple different sections for multiple different science topics, my favourite one is the space section!! There is a place where you could go in and lay your self down on a massage chair something like that. Then it will show a screen of stars a journey of the whole GALAXY!! The simulation was impressive and amazingly beautiful! Overall Highly recommended to spent time with your family, friends or your own time!!

I went to see the Grandma Moses exhibition.  Even though we went at opening time, there were a lot of people.  There were so many wonderful works that it is hard to believe that she first picked up her brush at the age of 78.

Some of the works that left an impression on me were purchased as postcards and kept.  I was glad to see Jonathan Borofsky's Hammering Man in front of the exhibition hall.  This is because Korea also has the world's largest hammering man at a height of 22m.
Amazing museum designed by Kisho Kurokawa, well known architect that also designed National art museum in Tokyo.

I personally didn't like it.
They don't allow you to take pictures. Who goes to a museum which doesn't really have new art, only old school style, already shared everywhere else and doesn't let you take photos.
Quite overpriced I would say.
Nothing very important and meaningful to see.
I would say check the museum next to it, the science one.

Went there for the permanent exhibition, not Gaudi. Gaudi exhibition is 1,800yen and the permanent one is 300yen. No taking pictures. Well, it is normal not that amazing art works but good. The only problem is that there is not English explanation at all… Overseas tourists become to visit Nagoya, so I think Nagoya city need to prepare the globalization. Anyway staff are all amazing and you can pay the ticket for the permanent exhibition on B1F in front of the entrance.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-13-2 Higashisakura, Higashi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 461-0005, Japan
data.name: Aichi Prefectural Museum Of Art

reviews.text: I went on a weekday so it was not crowded at all. Decent exhibits and it was enjoyable to view them without much of a crowd. A little annoying with limited photography allowed and no particularly notable exhibits. Spacious building but you can tell it hasn't seen any renovations for the last twenty years. Mid-tier museum shop.
I went this museum in 2016 for just going to Pablo Picasso exhibition. This exhibition really broaden my my knowledge about the painter. Museum itself wasn't too big and beautifully decorated.
Professional, friendly and courteous staff. Great experience. The Trialogue museum was worth the visit. Also greatly enjoyed the Japanese video displays.
Some parts were closed. The galleries that were open were cute; they displayed calligraphy made by students, I think. There were also marketing (?) displays made by students from a nearby university
good place and many good exhibitions in here as well as all staff are very kind. I really recommened for who love to see artworks should come in this museum.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-19-30 Aoi, Higashi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 461-0004, Japan
data.name: Mazak Corporation

reviews.text: I really enjoyed going here, and it was well worth the 1000¥ to go. Had a wonderful display of French art and furniture. Audio in English included with tour. My only improvement would be that on the 4th floor numbers are actually in order.

Had a brilliant experience here. Admission comes with a free audio tour, which has been done really well.
Learnt a lot and will definitely be back.
You aren't allowed to take photos of a few of the paintings. This caught me out once, and the lady had to stop me 😬
Two floors of unique collection but a bit pricey because not so much galleries showed

Small private museum in Nagoya with a wonderful collection of masterpieces of French furniture (end 19th and early 20th century) and paintings (17th through 20th century). Temporary exhibitions are also organized throughout the year. Quite and enjoyable atmosphere.
The museum gives a great experience of the Fench paintings, furniture and the glass works. Highly recommended.

data.formatted_address: 4-chōme-1-35 Noritakeshinmachi, Nishi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 451-0051, Japan
data.name: Toyota Commemorative Museum of Industry and Technology

reviews.text:
This museum is a very good place to visit for both adults and children. You can learn how the waving system can develop to be a car engine. There is an English narrator in some section too.

There are plenty of car park for free in the museum area.

This should be the number one tourist attraction in Nagoya.. so many interesting and interactive stations, we initially planned to stay there for a limited time and do Nagoya castle but ended up just doing this half the day.. we would have stayed longer if it wasn’t for hunger… also there’s lots of resting areas and a cafe.

This place was simply amazing. There were so many great things to see. And I love the transition of Toyota from the fabric industry into the automotive industry.

There were a lot of interactive exhibits and also stations where the staff would do demonstrations and show us how the different machines operate.

Definitely a must visit when stopping by Nagoya.

An interesting museum on the history of the Toyoda/Toyota company. I was not aware of their textile past and innovation with loom machines before they got into the automotive industry.

There are demonstrations of the looms and automotive manufacturing equipment by the staff of a regular basis. Rather concerning was the fact that the staff were not wearing any ear protection for the very loud equipment which they are around all day.

Big display of Toyota cars from 1920s to today. You have to be really into engineering and cars to get the true value out of this museum.

This is an incredible museum.
If you’re a technology fun or an history enthusiast, this is an absolute must.
It has two sections, one for the weaving history of Toyoda (the original name) and the other for the automotive history.
Both are absolutely fascinating.
Many live demonstrations and working machines.

We spent there 3 hours and wish we add more time.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-1-21 Aoi, Higashi Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 461-0004, Japan
data.name: Yokoyama Museum

reviews.text: I recommend it because it's a lot of fun and has a lot of beautiful ceramics. I get excited. It is OK to take photos inside the museum. Special exhibition: 1,000 yen, regular price: 700 yen (QR payment accepted). It's pretty empty on weekdays. No private parking lot.

It was good. The exquisitely crafted ceramics lined up in rows as if asking you to look at them as you like are a sight to behold, and you can take as many photos as you like. (Flash ☓) When I went, I was alone in the exhibition room and could see as much as I wanted without worrying about other people. Recommended for people like me who want to take their time and appreciate it.

This is a museum specializing in ceramics.
I went there to kill some time, but it's a very nice museum. I thought it would be very empty since it only sells ceramics, but it seemed to be popular with people who were interested and was quite busy. It seems that a curator's tour was also planned, and there were about 20 participants.
The exhibition space is located on the 1st to 5th floors, and you can take the elevator up to the top floor and go down the stairs while looking at the exhibits, but you can go back and forth freely, so you can view as many times as you like from the floor that interests you.
It was a museum that I wanted to come back to, as I was able to see a variety of crafts related to Nagoya, such as Noritake, as well as Seto ware and Banko ware.

I visited on a trip to Nagoya.
It was great! It's a highly recommended spot for those who come to Nagoya (especially for those who like art and handicrafts). You can enjoy the splendor of Japanese ceramics that were mainly exported overseas during the Meiji and Taisho periods. Luxury items, items of exquisite craftsmanship, etc....You can feel extremely luxurious while viewing them.
Nearby is the Yamazaki Mazak Museum of Art, and a little further away are the Tokugawa Art Museum and the Aichi Prefectural Museum of Art...How about visiting art museums?

I thought it was only Noritake, but there was a wide range of ceramics in general. There are very few exhibitions of free trade arts and crafts like this in Japan, so why not head to the Victoria and Albert Museum in Nagoya? Originally, the city museum should have spent money collecting it. Owari Tokugawa suddenly became like this.

reviews.text:
Lovely little museum ship, the second commissioned for Japanese Antarctic expeditions. Has a nice little museum on board and also an old helicopter. I came of a rainy day, so sadly the bridge was off limits. Still lots to see and do! get the ticket with the observation deck and the maritime museum, a steal at 710 JPY for all three!

I came during golden week and it still wasn't crowded.

p.s. you can buy the tickets at the observation deck of the tower itself, or even at the ship.

Was here on a very nice day in April.
The ship is very well preserved and looks to be in great shape. The information signs are in japanese only, but there is an qr code to an english version you can read on your phone.
The entry fee was also very reasonable.
You can buy tickets at a vending machine right outside the entrance to the ship.
It was very enjoyable

This was such a nice place to visit. The shop is kept very well. Everything is well cared for and the displays are great. Alot of it is in Japanese but some displays have English. They have guides that can help you if it is needed. It offers great views of the area. The helicopter is cool. You can buy a ticket just for this ship or a combo ticket for the ship, observation tower, and aquarium for a good price.
It is a good place to visit. A few people in evening. You can buy ticket at ticket machine and can see around Nagoya port.

In the center of the bustling Nagoya Port district, it's impossible to miss the large orange and white ship with the helicopter on top. That's the "Fuji" - an ice-breaking vessel used primarily on Antarctic expeditions and now retired to the status of a floating museum.  A trip onboard the ship is another neat little part of the fun district around the Port.
The Fuji was the premier ice breaking vessel of its era, hence being given its prestigious name. It first set sail in July of 1965, and took part in 18 Antarctic exploration trips between 1965 and 1983.
A trip aboard the Fuji is a step into a very different kind of life.  The crew that worked on this ship lived in close quarters, and how they went about their daily lives is a big feature of this attraction.  Visitors can wander the maze of the below-deck setup, seeing the bunks, the barber shop, where the crew ate, and where they relaxed.  Rooms are carefully preserved, and are filled with era-appropriate props to give a realistic glimpse at the ship in its "working state."  Many rooms even have mannequins playing checkers or writing letters to their loved ones at home to give a good image of what life was like on board.
On the top deck of the ship, guests can get up close and personal with a helicopter (although not go inside), and in front they are welcome to climb into the cockpit to man control of the steerage system.
To give an image of the size of the ship based on its specifications: the ship is an even 100 meters long, 22 meters wide, and 11.8 meters deep. When active, its maximum speed was 17 knots, equivalent to about 19.5 miles per hour (or 31.5 kilometers per hour).  It could hold 3 helicopters, 5 boats, and several hundred people at its maximum capacity.

Various efforts have been made to brighten the lighting and colors in the facility, and the smartphone/tablet app ``GO! GO! data.name: Old Nagoya Castle (Ruins)

reviews.text: Rocks. Open space

🚗subway、bus
💰ticket ¥500

It is said that Nagono Castle, the residence of Nobuhide Oda, was originally built around the Ninomaru Garden of Nagoya Castle.
It was originally the castle of the Imagawa family, but it is said to have been stolen.

Now, only the stone monument remains, but unfortunately it was burnt during the air raids during World War II, and only part of the inscriptions can be read.

In fact, there is a theory that his son, Lord Oda Nobunaga, was born at Nagono Castle.
(Currently, however, the Katsuhata Castle theory seems to be more correct.)

One of the remaining remains related to Nagoya Castle is Nagono Shrine, which was located within the castle grounds and was moved to the side of the current Nagoya Toshogu Shrine in the Meiji period.

It was said that Tokugawa Ieyasu tried to relocate it because it was getting in the way when he was rebuilding Nagoya Castle, but he gave up after being told by a fortune-telling that it was impossible.
As a heavy user of Nobunaga's Ambition, this Nagoya Castle is more familiar to me than the current Nagoya Castle. Nobunaga's "ambition" began from this castle...
It may not be a very common place, but it is the ruins of Nagono Castle, which was built in front of Nagoya Castle. It might be a good idea to feel a little bit of history here.

reviews.text: The place is ok, some gardening view. however definitely is not well managed as for the standard in Japan. we will rather just go to other parks nearby.

If lucky enough, you can see people with traditional Japanese wedding dresses to take their wedding photos, hereby I would like to congratulate this cute couple 💟
There is a sort of tea house, if you have got time you can try their tea set dessert, which I really love it! Overall, this is a good place to visit.
The most beautiful garden I have seen in Japan. Amazing, peaceful japanese garden.. bridges... Waterfall... Beautiful.

Holy mackerel this place is not to be missed. You have to see it if you're in Nagoya. So supremely relaxing and beautiful. Try to get into the tea house gardens if you can, and make your way up to the bamboo gardens, the waterfall and mini mountain. Could spend hours here.

Beautiful garden, especially in early spring.   We visited on a Saturday and didn’t find the grounds to be crowded at all. Parking was 300¥ and the entrance fee wasn’t bad. Lots of room to run around and explore - the garden is much larger than it looks from the outside. Absolutely worth a visit.

data.formatted_address: 1-3 Minatomachi, Minato Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 455-0033, Japan
data.name: Port Of Nagoya Public Aquarium

reviews.text:
One of the better aquariums in Asia, and definitely in Japan. Has a lot of varied exhibits that put attention and detail into the animals being displayed. Ticket prices are generally good and you can easily spend an entire day here with what is on-offer.

Can be a bit busy though, so do expect to wait to enter on weekends and holidays - it can also get quite cramped inside.

Visited on a Thursday morning in March. There was a crowd and thus were required to queue up for around 20 minutes to purchase the entrance tickets.

The aquarium was nice, where we are able to watch 15 minutes of live  dolphin and orca training at 11am and 12pm, respectively. The performances were definitely the highlight of the aquarium.

The other exhibits were just fine, and there are better aquariums for that elsewhere.

Definitely advise to go to the port area earlier and spend some time in the port area before visiting the aquarium

Definitely one of the best aquarium that we've ever visited. It basically a building that was built around a giant tank. Buy tickets online and head straight to the entrance, don't waste your time queuing on the ticket counters, it can be very time consuming especially on the weekends when half of Nagoya residents come here. Visit on the weekdays when possible. Easy access using subway train. Stock up on food from the minimarkets outside, I recommend Mini Stop because of their decent prices. Dolphins and orcas show is a must, better come early if you want to get a seat with better view. I would recommend this place if you have children, but it's fun for all ages. The center piece I think is the huge glass window that shows the aquarium and you can just sit there for some time admiring those creatures. I just feel pity for them living there for their whole lifetime.

The facilities are very well maintained and the aqualife are very healthy and active. I really liked the orca (killer whale) and my son liked the very active penguins. Highly recommend paying a bit more for the 4-in-1 ticket to visit the observation tower/maritime museum/retired antartic boat.

I went there during weekends, it was not too crowded so I could get a good view of the animals. The dolphin show was amazing, it’s a must-watch! You can also get a mesmerizing sea view outside of the aquarium.

data.formatted_address: 7 Chome Tomeicho, Chikusa Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 464-0028, Japan
data.name: Nagoya Higashiyama "Living Forest"

reviews.text:
I went to a place that I had been interested in for a while because I had some time, and it was a nice place full of nature.

There are places near my house, such as Idaka Ryokuchi and Makinogaike Ryokuchi, which are nice places, but what makes this place different is that there is a stream in the center of the greenery.

Around the stream, there are grassy fields, large and small ponds, wetlands, rice fields, and charcoal grilling huts, and the north, south, and east sides of the stream form a ridge-like ridge, making it look like a ``small mountain climbing course.''

On the ``Slight Mountain Climbing Course'' is an unnamed peak of 104.9m, which is just a little short of the height of Mt. Shinran, which boasts the second highest elevation in Nagoya City in the Inodaka Green Park, and on a clear day, Mt. Ontake can also be seen. Apparently.

Beyond the ridge on the north side, in the area bordering Peace Park, there is an alder wetland (actually, it's almost a pond) and a place where eucalyptus, a favorite of koalas, is grown, making it quite fun.

Although it is a small village forest, it is a place with many interesting things.

Good for collecting insects with children. There are ponds and waterways, so you can catch crayfish. If you go up the stairs and go towards the mountain, you will find a Chichizemi. Since you are not in the city, you can feel the richness of nature.

I took a walk in Satoyama today.
Low-bye and red low-bye are in full bloom😀
Contrast of white and red low-bye clothes
It was wonderful 🙆
Please look at the photo 🙏
Now is the best time to see it 🙋 Please come and visit us 🙇‍♀️

This is our number one place to walk.
Although it is close to the center of Nagoya, the natural forest is well preserved.
You can enjoy the relaxing course or the secret course. I wonder where I'm going from here... There are also exciting courses.
You can also enjoy the autumn leaves in November.

Formerly a more untouched and pristine natural place within Nagoya City.
It was a valuable place, but before I knew it, a group of ignorant elderly people
The park was smugly toyed with, calling itself ``creating a forest,'' and the sidewalks were made of concrete and gravel, making it a very cheap-looking park.
It seems that the word ``nature'' is used quite a lot on the website, but if you have even the slightest sense of shame, I think it would be a good idea to look up the meaning in a dictionary.

Inside, there is a full Museum and observation deck.

But there is no Mitan and Portan stamps!

The view was fantastic and there's a place where you can wear a seaman uniform and pretend you're driving a ship. There are a lot of 3D activities to try as well, like driving a ship and lifting containers in a port.

reviews.text: It's definitely a nice place to stop by when you visit nagoya. It has a great view to the nagoya city , oasis 21.

The TV tower area is nice, there's a large open area there that had a bunch of people singing, dancing and taking pictures of all the women dressed up which was very interesting to see. If you go to the top of the open area which had an elevator or stairs you can get a great view of the tower and city.

One of the top tourist spot here in Nagoya. It's free to go to the rooftop spaceship-aqua and see a good view. Also recently in this area you will see a good photo spot that has the letters NAGOYA spelled out. Enjoy this beautiful city.

data.formatted_address: Kameiri-1-8 Tashirochō, Chikusa Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 464-0803, Japan
data.name: Higashiyama Sky Tower

reviews.text: This is one of the famous tourist spot here in Nagoya. We get to Hajigaoka Station and from there, we just walk going to the tower. The entrance is just ¥300 for adult. There is also a 360 degrees view of the whole Nagoya. It was really nice thou and on the top floor of it is a classy restaurant wherein you can also have a nicer view of the place.

When I am visiting cities, I look for high vantage points to get a bird’s eye view, I found that this tower was a good point of view, standing at over 100 metres high you can see much of Nagoya. The observation deck provides 360-degree views of the city and surrounds, on a hot summer’s day the refreshing air-con is a welcome relief, I was up here on a Sunday and there were many visitors/tourists that came up here, I had an hour or so to kill and I sat up here enjoying the view and the comfortable environment, there’s a little gift shop there too. No matter how old or young this tower is a worthwhile visit. The tower is about a 20-minute walk from the train station, be warned that one of the roads leading up to the car park from the main street is quite steep so if you struggle with steep inclines, it may be wise to catch a taxi up there.

Good vantage point to view from a high over the zoo. The autumn foliage viewed from above is amazing. It isn’t so much a tower more like a high lookout point. Good to pay a visit if you are already in the zoo.

The Sky Tower will give you a beautiful 360 scenery of the zoo and the city. I particularly like the view of the lake with its colorful boats and seal pool. The staff are kind and helpful. Worth the visit.
I was finally able to visit the tower after living in Nagoya for almost a year. The view is beautiful, and you can see Mirai Tower and Mode Gakuen on a clear day!

data.formatted_address: 4-chōme-7-1 Meieki, Nakamura Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 450-0002, Japan

reviews.text: This place is cool. It is an open-air observatory offering 360 degree views of Nagoya City, plus a small bar with food. So nice view for both daytime and night time. The entrance ticket is just ¥1000 for adults.
¥1000 per adult and it's definitely worth it! Even on a day with mist and low clouds, the view was spectacular! The staff were also very helpful. Highly recommend

Some lovely views of the city, I would like to go back again at sunset or sunrise. There is lots of comfy seating so you could easily spend a few hours relaxing with friends or reading a book etc. I think there is also a bar but it wasn't open when I visited. Also it's worth it just for a ride in the lift, which goes so high your ears pop!

This is apparently the tallest building in Nagoya, and you can get a great view over the entire city as well as the surrounding mountains. Went here on a weekday around sunset. There were almost no people there, so stayed until it got dark.

I think this is an underrated place. It’s cozy and a nice place to chill. You can get a drink at the BBQ restaurant. And most importantly It’s not crowded at all. Recommend to come up here around sunset and stay a bit when it’s dark.

data.name: Heiwa Koen Aqua Tower

reviews.text:
The area around the tower is a park with walking paths. You can observe wild birds in the nearby forest. Recently, I was able to see the European Redstart, the White-eye, the Redfinch, the Blue-breasted Redstart, the great tit, and the osprey.
Flowering trees such as Japanese trumpet, camellia, hydrangea, and metasequoia can be seen beautifully in each season.

2022 (Reiwa 4) 1/23 13:00~

I stopped by this while walking around Peace Park! This is a water tower managed by the Nagoya City Water and Sewerage Bureau. There is an observation room on the top floor, from which you can see Mt. Sanage to the east and the Suzuka Mountains to the west.

The museum is open to the public from 10:00 to 16:00 on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, and is closed from 12/29 to 1/3. Admission is free. The inside of the building is well-maintained, equipped with air conditioning and heating, and staff are on hand. I have a good impression that they have taken good measures to prevent infectious diseases.

A Nagoya City Waterworks Bureau facility located in Peace Park.
The observation deck on the third floor is free.
Although it was a weekend when I visited, there weren't many people, so I was able to take my time to see it.
This time I only took photos for walking purposes. I walked from my house to the Hikarigaoka bus stop via Chayagasaka Park, Kanago Park, Peace Park 10,000-step course, and Rainbow Tower.

The Aqua Tower on the north side of Peace Park is used as a water distribution tower, so it is a building managed by the Nagoya City Water and Sewerage Bureau. Climbing the observation deck is free. First, we will disinfect your hands and take your temperature at the entrance. If there is no problem, the representative will be able to enter your name and contact information. From the observation deck, you can see mainly the south side of Nagoya. You can see the skyscrapers of Nagoya Station and Nagoya Port in the distance. However, it is only open on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.

reviews.text:
I have been here few times in few years, if you just visiting Nagoya, go first to Honmaru Castle. Restored wooden palace is such an amazing place to visit, such a great experience. I think it is really an architectural marvel.
The whole castle complex is worth visiting, go there in the morning preferably on a weekday, there is seasonal exhibitions take place. Like in the Autumn, different exhibitions for flowers, or Bonsai trees, etc. Walk around and enjoy this great place. There is place to rest if it's too hot outside and some nice little cafe and restaurants around the castle.

An interesting insight to how the palace used to look like and restored by amazing craftsmen down to every tiny detail.
It was a peaceful calm slowly observing each room as visitors were politely following the walkways and being respectful of their surroundings.
They offer audio guides in various languages for a small fee (iirc ¥100) and lockers for shoes and larger bags.

Free to enter after you paid for castle grounds and worth a quick visit. Apart from a few chests and decorated rooms there is also an interesting layout to see but nothing more. Moreover remember this is a restoration not an original piece, though still a nice one.
You will need to pay for admission to Nagoya castle to come here. Inside is extremely beautiful. The golden walls were stunning. Many rooms to enjoy. Definitely go if you’re in Nagoya!
Beautiful Japanese architecture and palace grounds, steeped in history.  Good food and snacks, and a lovely way to spend a few hours in Nagoya

data.name: Imagawa Yoshimoto Memorial Monument

reviews.text:
It is said that Yoshimoto Imagawa was killed at this place. With a large army of 25,000 people, it must have been an extremely painful experience. I apologize for your condolences.

Even if you have an overwhelming advantage, you can't let your guard down.

In today's world, even large companies cannot be said to have peace of mind throughout their lives.

It looks like a memorial stone monument located at the place where Yoshimoto Imagawa died in Okehazama Battlefield Park. It was a famous battle in history, so I reported to the cenotaph that Yoshimoto Imagawa's name still stands today. It is located in a small well-maintained park in a residential area. Please note that there is no parking lot.

Visited on December 27, 2023.
This area, called Dengakutsubo, is said to be the place where Imagawa Yoshimoto was defeated by Oda Nobunaga's forces during the Battle of Okehazama in 1560. The tombstone is engraved with the words ``Sunko Boketsu''.

This is another old battlefield of the Battle of Okehazama.
Until now, it has been said that the Battle of Okehazama was when the Oda army defeated Yoshimoto Imagawa in a surprise attack, but in recent years, research into Oda Nobunaga's primary sources seems to have changed the interpretation to the fact that he defeated Yoshimoto Imagawa in a direct attack. .
This old battlefield site has statues of Oda Nobunaga and Imagawa Yoshimoto, and on the south side of the park is a diorama depicting Nobunaga's march route from Kiyosu Castle to Okehazama, which was interesting to see.
There was a giant hornet around the water, so I ran away immediately.
Please be careful if you go.

☆A section of Okehazama Battlefield Park
Leading 25,000 soldiers, he marched triumphantly from Suruga to Mikawa and Owari, crushing Oda Nobunaga to pieces, but was disappointed when he lost his life at Dengakutsubo, the place where Yoshimoto Imagawa was killed ⚔️

From the left
“The place where Yoshimoto Imagawa died in battle” monument
“Yoshimoto Imagawa” Monument
“Sunko Boketsu” Monument
The mysterious stone monument on the far right is ``Shungong's tombstone'' (a tombstone is a tombstone with rounded corners), a mysterious stone buried in Dengakupyeong, who built it, why it was built, the year, etc. is completely unknown, it is a delusion. Perhaps the residents of Okehazama buried the body of Yoshimoto Imagawa, who was defeated by the pitiful Oda forces, in a grave, or perhaps they quietly buried it so that the enemy Oda family would not find it.This is also a small historical mystery. 🤔

reviews.text:
R DEUTSCH JAPANISCHEN FREUNDSCHA

honorable history
In 1915, the German Nagoya concentration camp was established here, and during World War I, a total of 519 people lived there for five years until 1920.

There was a library with a large collection of books, a daily newspaper was published, and the playground had various facilities such as football, tennis, gymnastics, and an orchestra, making it an open space.

It was rare for so many Germans to live in Nagoya, so the local residents treated them as if they were guests from afar, and were interested in the culture of Germany, a developed country, and had many interactions with them.

The residents of Mifukuro were particularly impressed by the hard-working lifestyle of the German people, learned a lot from their excellent vocational skills, used this knowledge to promote local industry, and deepened their friendships through music and sports.

Therefore, I believe that erecting a monument at this site and conveying the facts of history to future generations is truly meaningful and a measure of international friendship.

March 2003
Honorary Chair of the Federal Republic of Germany in Nagoya Kohei Abe
Chairman of the Japanese-German Association of Nagoya Ishiguro Isao

data.name: Glasses Monument

reviews.text:
"Monument of Glasses"
Among the Jomon pottery, this is a close-up view of a clay figurine that has been rumored to be an alien.
This is a replica.
This shading clay figurine was installed in 1982, with permission from Atsuta Shrine, to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Nagoya Optical Cooperative Association.

The original shading clay figurine was excavated from the Tsugaru City wooden Kamegaoka ruins, which is owned by the Tokyo National Museum, and is designated as an important cultural property.
It is a large hollow clay figurine, and almost its entire shape can be seen except for the missing right leg. The legs are short, the waist is strongly bulging, and the torso has an arabesque-like curved pattern all over. The eyes are large ovals with a single horizontal line drawn in the shape of a so-called ``shade'', and the head has a complex crown-like decoration. This is an excellent piece that shows the advanced craft techniques achieved by Kamegaoka culture. Although it has a deformed shape overall, the presence of breasts indicates that, like most other clay figurines, it is a representation of a woman.
This clay figurine was excavated in April 1887, and introduced to the newly formed central academic society in October of the same year. Due to this background, it can be said to be the most famous shading clay figurine.

There is a blackout clay figure as a monument to glasses.
I searched for sculptures and found it, so I took a photo of it.
I liked the cute design

It was built by the Nagoya Optical Cooperative Association.

It is the principal image of the Meganekko Sect, so if you think of the Shintoism of the Meganekko Sect, it is recommended that you visit.
A fine clay figurine-style monument. It's nothing more or less than that, but I'd like you to stop by if you can. It's kind of soothing.
The sculptures on this monument look like extraterrestrial artifacts. Although I don’t know where they came from, I can’t help but want to take a closer look when I pass by.

data.name: 名古屋市蓬左文庫

reviews.text:
This is a facility where old books are kept.
Because it is located adjacent to the Tokugawa Art Museum and Tokugawaen,
It's easy to understand.
I was moved to see such valuable books.

This place was like a library during the Edo period.
If you get permission inside, you can read old materials.
Part of the Tokugawa Art Museum? You can also enter only the reading room (exhibition room?) It's exciting because you enter through a strange entrance.
If you have a disability certificate, the reading room is free.
You cannot enter the Tokugawa Art Museum.
Equipped with coin lockers
It might be fun to go see it if you have some free time.
You can view the materials in the room that also has a desk.
Books cannot be borrowed
Houza is the old name for Nagoya.

The core of this collection is what used to be the collection of the Owari Domain Library. After Ieyasu's death, the library began with approximately 3,000 copies of Sunpu's books handed down to his son Yoshinao, and with successive feudal lords adding to the collection, the library currently has approximately 110,000 books. Before the war, it was located in Tokyo, but after the war it was moved back to its hometown of Nagoya, and now it is under the jurisdiction of Nagoya City thanks to a donation from the Tokugawa family. In the reading room, you can see printed copies of classics such as Kinjo Onkoroku and Parrot Chuuki.
In the entrance hall, a video called ``Digital Bunko'' introduces masterpieces from Hoza Bunko. There are 13 programs in total, and it will take about 90 minutes to watch them all, but there are many interesting contents such as ``Suruga Goshobon (Tokugawa Ieyasu's collection)'' and ``History of Hosa Bunko'', so If you have time, please check it out.
In addition to paper books, Hoza Bunko also produces and sells digital versions of the Nagoya Series. The first one is ``Kinjo Onkoroku''. The second edition is the diary of Genroku Tatami Magistrate Asahi Bunzaemon Shigeaki, ``Paromeme Chuuki.''

I went to see the special exhibition ``Master! Appraisal of Edo''. ``The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter'' was displayed at the entrance of the venue, so I thought it was a fake manuscript of ``The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter'', but it was not so.It was to introduce the story related to the first forgery depicted in the story. . In ``The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter'', Princess Kaguya requests one of her suitors, ``Kuramochi no Oji'', to fetch ``Hōrai's jade branch.'' In response, the prince orders a craftsman to make a branch of Horai's jewel, in an attempt to deceive Princess Kaguya. The plan was about to succeed, but something unexpected happened and the prince's lies were discovered. In a book I read a while ago, it was written that the ``Kuramochi no Oji'' depicted here was a satire of a real-life politician from the Asuka period. Who is that? If you are interested, please check it out. The name "Kuramochi no Oji" is a hint. I wrote a long article about something that has nothing to do with the exhibition. The introduction was so excellent that I couldn't help but want to write about it. Not bad.
Aside from that, I think this exhibition was more interesting than the exhibits themselves because of the various anecdotes surrounding the appraisals. Prices began to be attached to works of art from around the Muromachi period, and the authenticity of works of art became uncertain depending on the era.In addition, in the last corner of ``Appraisal in a difficult situation'', ``Appraisal should be strict, but appraisal The difficult part of appraisal is that the person receiving the appraisal expects a lenient appraisal.'' This has not changed since then.
2023.629

I went to see the special exhibition ``The World of Noh: Gods, Men, Women, Madness, Demons''. As the title suggests, this is an exhibition about Noh, including explanations of Noh programs, Noh masks, Noh costumes, props, and musical instruments. I had never seen a Noh performance before, but I learned a lot about Noh and found it very interesting.
There was a detailed explanation about Noh in the entrance. As always, photography of exhibits is prohibited, but unfortunately photography was also prohibited for this explanation. I wanted to take a photo of it because it explained Noh in detail, but I think that if this booklet had been sold as a booklet, people's understanding of Noh would have deepened considerably, but it was a shame that it wasn't there. .
2023.4.18

I went to see the special exhibition "Tokugawa Bunbo Haku." This time too, the exhibition was limited to Hosa Bunko, but it was very interesting. ``Bunbo'' originally meant ``a cell or government office in charge of documents in the imperial court,'' but also ``a literary person's study.'' The tools used there are called "stationery." Among them, inkstones, brushes, ink, and paper are called the ``Four Treasures of Bunbo,'' and have been particularly contrasted with Shohen. It was very interesting to be able to see many masterpieces of stationery owned by the Tokugawa Art Museum. By the way, the Tokugawa Museum of Art owns about 500 ancient ink paintings, which is said to be a world-class collection. That's surprising!
I didn't have an illustrated catalog this time either, but I wish I had made one if possible.
2023.1.26

I went to see the special exhibition "Falconry". This special exhibition is only available at Hosa Bunko.
Even though I was ignorant, I knew that falconry is a type of hunting that uses a falcon, but I didn't know the details at all. However, it was interesting to learn a lot about falconry at this exhibition.
In addition to exhibiting works of art related to falconry, Mr. Gomakichi, who is still active as a falconer, will be exhibiting stories such as ``Hawks are very delicate and timid,'' ``They are so sensitive that they can die from stress,'' and ``They are very close to humans.'' It was very interesting to hear about the ecology of hawks, which you can't imagine from their appearance. It's a pity that there is no illustrated catalog for such an interesting exhibit. I wish they had made it, even if it was just a booklet.
The exhibit also included an explanation about the difference between a hawk and an eagle. I've been having this problem since I was a kid, and this has finally solved it! If you want to know the difference between a hawk and an eagle, please come to the venue!
2022.11.23

I went to see the autumn special exhibition ``Specialties - Treasures with a timely history.'' The venue is both Hosa Bunko and Tokugawa Art Museum, but Hosa Bunko has famous swords on display. It seems that the origin of the specialty is that special names were given to excellent vessels in ancient times, which is interesting. Also on display at the venue are swords called ``Yakimono'' and ``Yakimi'' that have been reheated after being set on fire. If these were prized, does this mean that they valued not only the sword's creator or its artistic value, but also its history?
2022.10.20

I saw the special exhibition "The World of Festivals: Elegance and Costumes." Since I went there twice, I was able to see both the ``Toyokuni Festival Folding Screen'' and the ``Nagoya Toshogu Festival Folding Screen.'' Needless to say, the Toyokuni Festival is a festival of Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
Lately, it feels like Hideyoshi's loneliness and impatience in his later years have been emphasized, but looking at the enthusiasm of the people depicted on this folding screen, I wonder if that was actually true. I will. Of course, people at the time may have just wanted to make a fuss to vent their daily frustrations, regardless of Hideyoshi's evaluation.
In any case, it's a good idea to hold this exhibition at this time of year when the Domatsuri festival is held in Nagoya.
2022.8.30

Basically, it is a free facility.

It has a collection of books related to the Owari Tokugawa family, which can be viewed by making a reservation.

On the right side as you enter, there is an information corner for events in Aichi Prefecture. Mainly flyers.

data.formatted_address: Makinoga Pond, Maeyama Idakacho Oaza Takabari, Meito Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 465-0067, Japan
data.name: Makinoga Pond

reviews.text:
Makino Pond was built for irrigation purposes in 1646 during the Edo period, and is the largest pond in the city, with an area of ​​16 ha (as of January 1989, it was approximately 23 ha). The surrounding area was once a hunting ground for the Owari Tokugawa family, and is now known as a visiting place for migratory birds.
In the past, the name was inconsistently written as ``Makiike,'' ``Makioike,'' ``Makinooike,'' and ``Makinoike,'' but in the Taisho period, the name was unified as ``Makinoike.'' However, when the city planning was decided in 1940, the surrounding area was incorrectly written as ``Makinogaike Green Area,'' and when it was turned into a park by the prefecture, that name was carried over, resulting in ``Makinogaike'' and ``Makinogaike.'' Various expressions have been used, including ``Noike''.
The local school district and Meito Ward appealed to the prefecture and city to return to the original name, and in July 2009, the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan asked the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan to revise the name of the pond, and the name was officially changed to ``Makino Pond.'' It became. Local residents have also requested that the name of the park be changed to ``Makinoike Ryokuchi''.
Along with Higashiyama Park and Peace Park, this is a walking course that represents Nagoya.

data.formatted_address: 47 Miharashichō, Minami Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 457-0026, Japan
data.name: Nagoya City Miharashidai Archeological Museum

reviews.text: Amazing! Created lot important feeling and ideas.

The archaeological museum, which was built after excavations on this hill where it flourished during the Yayoi period, exhibits excavated earthenware and stone tools, allowing you to immerse yourself in the romance of history.
This hill was also used as an anti-aircraft gun base during the Pacific War, and approximately one-third of the archaeological museum exhibits artifacts related to the war. There are two gun emplacements left in the plaza outside, and you can imagine the sad scenes of war with your own eyes.
There is a parking lot for about 21 cars, admission is free, and there is also a plum garden and a plaza, perfect for a light picnic, and a great place for families up to elementary school age to spend time together.
The view of Kasadera Kannon from the hill is peaceful and wonderful.
It might be a good idea to visit at sunset, but the museum closes at 5 p.m., so the parking lot will probably be closed as well.

In April 2024, I stopped by on my way to Chukyo Racecourse by bicycle. Ruins from the Jomon and Yayoi periods have been found, and anti-aircraft equipment and military barracks were reportedly built there during World War II. At the museum, you can see pottery with round windows, and the manga character ``Marudon'' is unique and cute.
O Museu Arqueológico de Miharudai da cidade de Nagoya é uma instalação que coleta, pesquisa e exibe materiais relacionados às Ruínas de Miharudai.A entrada é gratuita.

Museum built on ruins
I went for the first time in early August 2023.
The museum, which opened in 1979, is located on top of the observation deck ruins in Kasadera Park and can be viewed for free.
The inside of the building has a Showa-era feel, but it is kept clean.
The permanent exhibition introduces earthenware and stone tools unearthed during excavations at the Miharodai ruins. There are also exhibits related to anti-aircraft gun positions during the Pacific War.
In the attached dwelling ruin observation building, the excavated pit dwelling ruins are recreated in full-size replicas, and the dwellings have been restored.
There are Kasadera Kannon and Kasadera Ichirizuka nearby, so if you are a history buff, we recommend going there as a set.

data.formatted_address: Hyde Park, Elizabeth St, Sydney NSW 2000, Australia
data.name: Nagoya Gardens, Hyde Park Sydney

reviews.text: Beautiful park in the middle of CBD.. good place to relax..

A tranquil ambience and a beautiful historical landmark established as a celebratory gesture to the friendship of Sister city of Sydney and the Japanese city of Nagoya. It's a small yet impressive space that perched between the Hyde Park Chessboard, Busby's Bore Fountain and Archibald Fountain. There's few benches here to sit and watch the parade of workers, tourists, school children and everyone else of all description. This garden is a testament to community, cultural understanding and friendship. This idea of a Sister City was borne out of the mid 1950s whereby Dwight Eisenhower established Sister City programme to foster international understanding and peace. Nagoya Gardens in Hyde Park was named in 1983. The last major refurbishment of this garden was in 2004. This is a welcoming little oasis to relax and reflect. Suitable for all ages, wheelchair friendly. Closest public transportation is St James station, a minute walk away from here. Understated beauty.

data.formatted_address: 4-chōme-11-2 Noseki, Minato Ward, Nagoya, Aichi 455-0845, Japan
data.name: Nagoya City Birdwatching Center

reviews.text: Very organised. Have lots of information about birds. They have stuffed birds of many species in the showcase. You can touch the pheasants too, they feel like just the real birds, so awesome. There are multiple binoculars available for watching the sea shore birds closely. Play ground for kids, public toilets are available. A very calm and peaceful picnic place. Highly recommended for nature lovers and bird lovers.

If you like birds, I think you should definitely come here.
You can see wild birds and the scenery is beautiful!
There is also a children's play area, so it's fun for parents and children too.
Since there are sports fields, gymnasiums, and soccer fields in the surrounding area, it is difficult to park in the parking lot 🅿 when there is a tournament of some kind.

It's a plain building, and I went to the visitor's center next door and was about to leave.

I came from another prefecture to watch wild birds at Fujimae Tidal Flat, but the first time I went, I went to the wrong place. It feels like I've finally gotten to where I need to go, but the bird is further away than I expected.

This observation hall has glass-enclosed observation seats facing the tidal flats on the first and second floors, and field scopes are lined up in rows. The birds are so far away that you can barely see anything with the naked eye. The 8x binoculars I usually use are almost useless!

When I looked through the field scope, I was so impressed that there was an osprey there! It seems that you have set it up to some extent. I watched it for over 30 minutes, but this osprey seemed to like this little platform (quite a long way in front of the observation hall) and stayed there the whole time. I thought it moved just a little bit and then I realized I had a fish and I missed how I caught it. Tohoho, I caught fish twice while I was there. Amazing! Too bad I couldn't see it flying!

I went on a weekday around noon. The time of low tide and the number of birds seen today were written on the blackboard. There are quite a few stuffed animals on display. We were the only visitors, and no one appeared, so we had a relaxing time.

The field scope comes with a plastic wrap that you can remove and throw in the trash can at the exit.
If one seat was available, I would have used two seats, one for ospreys and one for birds in flight. (luxurious hope)
Fieldscopes have a narrow field of view, so it was impossible to point a cell phone at them and take pictures.

I'm not a birdwatcher, but just a companion, so it was great to be able to watch birds in a warm place. It's free!

I didn't go here because I rented a restroom in the building next door, but you can rent one here as well. (This is an important point for winter bird watching.)

I first learned about Fujimae Tidal Flat when I went to see it from Noseki in Minato Ward, Nagoya City.
There are about 10 telescopes installed on the first and second floors, allowing you to observe wild birds in the tidal flats. You can observe a variety of wild birds in each season, so I'd like to visit in the fall and winter as well.
There are also many stuffed birds on display in the museum.

There aren't many exhibits or space, but there are telescopes lined up on the first and second floors, allowing you to observe wild birds in the tidal flats.
There are also people in charge who kindly explain things to you.

Oasis21 consists of rooftop Spaceship-Aqua, Field of Green on the ground level, Bus Terminal on the first floor, and Galaxy Platform and shops in the basement level. The symbol of Oasis21 is Spaceship-Aqua, a representative landmark of Japan, and Field of Green is a precious space for recreation in the heart of the city. Also, Oasis21 is Nagoya’s transportation hub, possessing a Bus Terminal where a large number of bus lines stop in addition to direct connections to Sakae Station on the subway and Sakaemachi Station on Nagoya Railroad. Getting to nearby facilities is simple both above ground and below via accessway, escalators, and elevators.

reviews.text: Arrived here at 6:47PM. Shows open on Google maps until 10PM. It is closed. Info on gmaps incorrect. We wasted parking fee here.
Great place to view modern art and glimpses of Japanese culture depending on the exhibition. No English pamphlets or signage provided unfortunately.
I only visit the Oasis 21, but the building it's amazing for inside. outside is great, so that attendees can enjoy the atmosphere
I like this place so much, Have many good exhibition and good artwork diaplay in here, really highly recommend who love art.

The mini theatre is a nice spot to see a play. There is a restaurant on the top floor, and a cafe in the B1 Level. You can connect to Oasis 21 through the underground passage where you'll find lots of restaurants and shopping and the Sakae subway station (which is connected to 100's of shops!)

the place is nice but it's better if you don't watch it on the 5th floor because the view is not good. The rest is good
As always, a wonderful show, with great performances from the ballet company (Sochi International) and the orchestra.

Me and the family visited the Studio Ghibli exhibition early November. It had a nice layout and very cool things on display. The Neko Bus was very cool to sit inside of and we could take a photo sitting next to 'No-Face' on the rail car. Worth a visit.

I visited to this Art Theater on January 30 2023 for classic music lover, the founder of Yamada Sadao Foundation of 10th anniversary concert.

The space between the seats back & front seemed a little bit narrow.

data.formatted_address: Koi-281 Kumanoshō, Kitanagoya, Aichi 481-8503, Japan
data.name: Nagoya University of The Arts East Campus

reviews.author_name: Geo ジョーDee ディー
reviews.text:
A great campus with highly talented and creative young boys and girls. Loved interacting with some students here. Very helpful and professional staff and teachers.
The lounge named 'Accord' is a cool place for casual English lessons.
Very nice campus. It is aging but still quite nice. The visual depiction of bela bartoks work is very nice on th exterior
bad

I visited for the 2023.11 art festival. The campus was beautifully designed. Although it is not very large, I think it is a university with good facilities and environment. The school cafeteria was free. It was delicious and filling. Both the live performances and the stalls were wonderful.

I live nearby.
When I was a child, I went to the school festival every year.
From that time on, everyone called it Jiyu Gakuin.
There is also a Kurie Kindergarten attached to the school.
However, the area of ​​the school itself is not that large.
Also, the address around here is Kumanosho, Kitanagoya City, but for some reason the road in front of the school is an enclave of Kitanagoya City Rokutsushi.
I think there used to be a girls' dormitory on the school grounds, but it seems like the building is gone now.

Personally, I think it has a community-based atmosphere.
We even changed the name of the nearest Meitetsu station, and moved out of a business hotel next to the station and turned it into a school-related facility.
There are also lifelong learning programs and public concerts.

However, Kitanagoya City has not maintained any sidewalks on the road accessed from Tokushige Nagoya Geidai Station for many years, so commuting to school on Sakamaki Street is quite dangerous.
The road to the Faculty of Arts in the west feels equally dangerous.
Are there no plans for a school bus? Is it difficult because there is no bus stop at Tokushige/Nagoya Geidai Station?

Now that I think about it, we've been doing TV commercials a lot lately, and we're trying to get our name out there by hosting games at Vantelin Dome as a sponsor of the Dragons.

There was an album called ``Sakamaki Dori'' released by The Boy Meets Girls, a band formed by students here.
